sn41.9:1.1: The phrase purāṇagihisahāya (“old friend from the lay life”) appears only here and at MN 124:2.1. There it is also said of a naked ascetic (acela) called Kassapa, which cannot be a coincidence. The events of that discourse happened many decades after the Buddha’s death.
sn41.9:1.8: For nipphoṭanā (“pokes”), cf. Sanskrit prasphoṭana, “striking”. Apparently a reference to the discomfort of sitting on bare ground with bare buttocks.
sn41.9:2.4: Read kiñhi no siyā per BJT.
sn41.9:2.10: That is to say, he was a non-returner.
